Blueberry Cherry Pie blog recipes

24 November 2012

This Thanksgiving I made a pie. Making pie is a huge pain, but definitely worth it. I was going to cheat a bit and use pre-made pie crust, but after thinking about it, I couldn't bring myself to do it. Crust is my favorite part of the pie! So I broke down and made some crust, and filled it with some delicious blueberry-cherry filling. Recipe below.

Rolling out the crust. Best pie crust recipe from Smitten Kitchen.

I started with a bare bones blueberry cherry filling that called for frozen blueberries and cherry pie filling. A little basic, if you ask me. Needles to say I improved. A bit.

And then made a fancy lattice top with the crust. As much as I love crust, I can't resist the urge to make a pretty lattice.

And then I baked it, and let it cool for a few torturous hours.

Then I dug in. And it was delicious. Sweet, spicy, and perfectly crispy.

Spiced Blueberry Cherry Pie

Modified from AllRecipes.com

Ingredients: crust

  • Refrigerated (or frozen) pie dough, or enough pie crust for a double crusted pie.
    • I use Smitten Kitchen's "All butter, really flaky pie dough" recipe.
Ingredients: filling
  • 1/2 cup white sugar
  • 2 T cornstarch
  • 1 T lemon juice
  • 1/4 t ground cinnamon
  • 1/4 t ground nutmeg
  • 1/8 t ground cloves
  • 1 24 oz. jar of cherries, drained
    • I used dark cherries in a syrup and sugar mixture and rinsed them. You can used frozen cherries, but make sure to defrost them first. 
  • 1 1/2 cup frozen blueberries, thawed
Ingredients: egg wash
  • 1 egg white
  • 1 t water
  • 2 t sugar
Directions
  1. Pre-heat over to 350 degrees.
  2. Roll out pie crust and line 9 inch pie dish with half of the crust. Tear off the extra and save it.
  3. In a medium size bowl, combine all ingredients for filling (sugar, cornstarch, lemon juice, nutmeg, cinnamon, cloves, cherries, and blueberries) and stir.
  4. Fill the pie with the contents from the bowl.
  5. Top the pie with the remaining crust. Make a fun design, or just lay it out evenly. Use a fork to make crimp marks along the edge of the pie.
  6. In a small bowl, beat egg white, water, and sugar together until thoroughly mixed. Using a pastry brush, brush the mixture across the top of the pie. Make sure you don't leave any puddles!
  7. Bake the pie in the oven for 60 minutes, rotating every 15 minutes to ensure that it cooks evenly.
  8. Remove the pie from the oven and place on a cooling rack for 2–3 hours.
  9. Serve warm (reheat if necessary!) with a side of ice cream. I promise it's tasty.

About pattern purchases

Patterns are sold as downloadable PDF files through Ravelry, with payments processed by PayPal. You do not need an account to use either service.

If you have a Ravelry account, I suggest logging in prior to purchasing so that patterns are added to your library.

Get pattern help

Pattern support is provided free of charge for all of my patterns. We respond as quickly as possible, but sometimes it can take a day or two.

Submit a new help request through Zendesk.

You can also use Zendesk to report errors and ask non-technical questions.

Alternatively, you can try the Ravelry group.

Support is only provided via Zendesk.

Not at this time.

Pattern wholesaling is temporarily on hold and should resume in 2014.

I found an error, how do I report it?

Oh newts! Submit your error through Zendesk and we will fix it.

Happy knitting!
